<!--https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/tags#tags__3-->
<h1>Tags</h1>            <div class="fcdo-s20">from <a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/english-grammar-today/" class="a--rev">English Grammar Today</a></div>
</div><div class="content"><div class="section_anchor" id="tags-uses"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Tags: uses</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>Tags are either questions, statements or imperatives added to a clause to invite a response from the listener:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">You’re a musician</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">aren’t you</i></b><i class="i">?</i></p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Well, yes, but I’m just an amateur</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">She can’t swim</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">can she</i></b><i class="i">?</i></p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">No. Apparently she never learnt as a child</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Donna plays football, <b class="b">doesn’t she</b>?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He was your teacher, <b class="b">was he</b>?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Pass me that CD</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">will you</i></b><i class="i">?</i></p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p">[passes the CD]</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Thanks</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="tags-form"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Tags: form</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>Tags consist of one of the auxiliary verbs<span class="target"/> <i class="i">be</i><i class="i"><span class="target"/>, do</i><i class="i"><span class="target"/></i> or <i class="i">have</i><i class="i"><span class="target"/></i>, or the main verb <i class="i">be</i><i class="i"><span class="target"/></i>, or a modal verb<span class="target"/>, plus a subject<span class="target"/>, which is most commonly a pronoun<span class="target"/>:</p><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">main clause</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">be, do, have</i>, modal</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">subject pronoun</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He<b class="b">’s</b> working as a tour guide,</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">isn’t</b></i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">he?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Your mother <b class="b">was</b> Scottish,</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">wasn’t</b></i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">she?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">She <b class="b">plays</b> the piano,</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">does</b></i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">she?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The shops <b class="b">don’t</b> open till 9.30,</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">do</b></i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">they?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">They<b class="b">’ve</b> moved,</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">have</b></i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">they?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You <b class="b">could</b> sell it on the Internet,</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">couldn’t</b></i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">you?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Don’t</b> <b class="b">be</b> late tonight,</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">will</b></i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">you?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><p class="p">When we use auxiliary <i class="i">be, do</i> or <i class="i"><span class="target"/>have</i>, a modal verb or main verb <i class="i">be</i> in the main clause, this verb is used in the tag:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">She <b class="b">was</b> crying, <b class="b">was</b>n’t she?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He <b class="b">does</b> look like his father, <b class="b">does</b>n’t he?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">They’<b class="b">ve</b> waited a long time, <b class="b">have</b>n’t they?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You’<b class="b">re</b> Danish, <b class="b">are</b>n’t you?</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">If there is no auxiliary or modal verb in the main clause, we use auxiliary <i class="i">do, does, did</i> in the tag:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He <b class="b">plays</b> hockey, <b class="b">does</b> he?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">She <b class="b">dances</b> beautifully, <b class="b">does</b>n’t she?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The girls <b class="b">wanted</b> to go home, <b class="b">did</b>n’t they?</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">If the main clause verb is <i class="i">I am</i><i class="i"><span class="target"/></i>, then the negative tag form is <i class="i">aren’t I</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Sorry, <b class="b">I’m</b> late again, <b class="b">aren’t</b> <b class="b">I</b>?</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">If the main clause <span class="target"/>verb is <i class="i">used to</i>, the tag verb is <i class="i">did</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Martin</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">used</i></b> <b class="b"><i class="i">to</i></b> <i class="i">live in Oxford</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">did</i></b><i class="i">n’t he?</i></p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Yes, that’s right</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote><p class="p">If the main clause verb is <i class="i">ought to</i><i class="i"><span class="target"/></i>, the tag verb is most commonly <i class="i">should</i> or, far less commonly, <i class="i">ought</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">ought</b> to leave now, really, <b class="b">should</b>n’t we?</i> Or (far less commonly) <i class="i">We</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">ought</i></b> <i class="i">to leave now, really</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">ought</i></b><i class="i">n’t we?</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">When tags follow imperatives, the tag verb is usually <i class="i">will</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><b class="b"><i class="i">Phone</i></b> <i class="i">me this evening</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">will</i></b> <i class="i">you?</i></p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Yeah, OK. I’ll give you a call about 6.30</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="question-tags"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Question tags</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>Question tags turn statements into <i class="i">yes-no</i> questions. There are two types.</p><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Type 1</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">The first type of question tag consists of an affirmative main clause and a negative tag, or a negative main clause and an affirmative tag. Negative tags are most commonly used in the contracted form:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[main clause]</span><span class="rb">She’s a translator</span></span>, <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[tag]</span><span class="rb"><b class="b">isn’t</b> she?</span></span></i> (affirmative main clause + negative tag)</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He hasn’t arrived yet, <b class="b">has he?</b></i> (negative main clause + affirmative tag)</p></blockquote><p class="p">We can use type 1 question tags when we expect the answer to the question to confirm that what we say in the main clause is true:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">You work with Barbara</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">don’t you</i></b><i class="i">?</i> (A thinks it is true that B works with Barbara.)</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Yes, that’s right</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Sam’s not very old</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">is he</i></b><i class="i">?</i> (A thinks it is true that Sam is not very old.)</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">No, he’s only 24</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote><p class="p">With type 1 tags, we can use falling intonation (↘) if we are fairly sure of the answer, and rising intonation (↗) if we are not so sure.</p><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Compare</span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">fairly sure</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">not so sure</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We’ve met before,</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">haven<span class="intonation-arrow">↘</span>’t we</b>?</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You were at Kim’s party,</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">weren<span class="intonation-arrow">↗</span>’t you</b>?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He’s not very happy,</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">is <span class="intonation-arrow">↘</span>he</b>?</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">They’re not open today,</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">a<span class="intonation-arrow">↗</span>re they</b>?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Type 2</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">The second type of question tag consists of an affirmative main clause and an affirmative tag:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[main clause]</span><span class="rb">You’<b class="b">re</b> Joe’s cousin</span></span>, <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[tag]</span><span class="rb"><b class="b">are</b> you?</span></span></i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">She <b class="b">got</b> the email, <b class="b">did she?</b></i></p></blockquote><p class="p">We can use type 2 tags when we do not know if the answer is <i class="i">yes</i> or <i class="i">no</i>. The intonation is usually a rising tone:<span class="target"/></p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Maureen</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">lives</i></b> <i class="i">in Hamden</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">does s<span class="intonation-arrow">↗</span>he</i></b>? (The speaker wants to know if Maureen lives in Hamden or not.)</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Yes, She does. She was born there in fact</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">You’</i><b class="b"><i class="i">re</i></b> <i class="i">a graphic designer</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">are</i></b> <i class="i">y<span class="intonation-arrow">↗</span>ou</i>?</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">No, not actually a designer, but I work with graphics</i>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Oh, right</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote></div></div></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="imperative-tags"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Imperative tags</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>A tag after an imperative clause softens the imperative a little. The tag verb is most commonly <i class="i">will</i> but we can also use <i class="i">would, could, can</i> and <i class="i">won’t</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Turn the TV down, <b class="b">will you</b>?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Don’t shout, <b class="b">will you</b>? I can hear you perfectly well.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Come here a minute, <b class="b">can you?</b></i></p></blockquote><p class="p">After the imperative with <i class="i">let’s</i>, we can use <i class="i">shall</i> in the tag:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Let’s</b> have some lunch now, <b class="b">shall we?</b></i></p></blockquote></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="statement-tags"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Statement tags</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We can use a statement tag to emphasise or reinforce an affirmative statement. The tag is also affirmative. They typically invite the listener to agree or sympathise in some way, or to offer a parallel comment. Statement tags are very informal:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">I</i><b class="b"><i class="i">’m</i></b> <i class="i">bored with this, I</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">am</i></b>. (stronger than <i class="i">I’m bored with this</i>)</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Me too</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">My Maths teacher was lovely. He</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">was</i></b> <i class="i">a great teacher, he</i> <b class="b"><i class="i">was</i></b>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Hm, you were lucky. Mine wasn’t so good</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote><p class="p">When the main clause <span class="target"/>has a pronoun subject, a statement tag can have a noun as the subject instead of a pronoun:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">She won some money last week</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">Catherine</i></b> <b class="b"><i class="i">did</i></b>.</p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Really?</i></p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Yeah</i>.</p></div></div></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He was a great teacher, <b class="b">Mr Mark was</b>.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">This construction is similar to a tail construction.</p><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/headers-and-tails">Headers and tails </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="universal-tags-right-yeah"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Universal tags: <i class="i">right, yeah</i></h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We can use <i class="i">right</i> and <i class="i">yeah</i> in very informal situations instead of question tags:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">So, you’re not coming with us tonight</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">right</i></b><i class="i">?</i></p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">No, I’m too busy. Sorry</i>. or (less informally) <i class="i">You’re not coming with us tonight</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">are you</i></b><i class="i">?</i></p></div></div></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">A:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">They’ll be here about 4.30</i>, <b class="b"><i class="i">yeah</i></b><i class="i">?</i></p></div></div><div class="utterance"><div class="speaker">B:</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><i class="i">Yeah. That’s what they said</i>. or (less informally) <i class="i">They’ll be here about 4.30, <b class="b"><i class="i">won’t they/will they</i></b></i>?</p></div></div></blockquote></div></div></div></div></article>
</div>
</div>
<div class="clrd">
<div class="mod float-xl">
<div id='ad_btmslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_b' class='am-default '>

<li class="section">
<a>Easily confused words</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/above-or-over"><i>Above</i> or <i>over?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/across-over-or-through"><i>Across</i>, <i>over</i> or <i>through</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/advice-or-advise"><i>Advice</i> or <i>advise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/affect-or-effect"><i>Affect</i> or <i>effect</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-every"><i>All</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-whole"><i>All</i> or <i>whole</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/allow-permit-or-let"><i>Allow</i>, <i>permit</i> or <i>let</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/almost-or-nearly"><i>Almost</i> or <i>nearly</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alone-lonely-or-lonesome"><i>Alone</i>, <i>lonely</i>, or <i>lonesome</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/along-or-alongside"><i>Along</i> or <i>alongside</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/already-still-or-yet"><i>Already</i>, <i>still</i> or <i>yet</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/also-as-well-or-too"><i>Also</i>, <i>as well</i> or <i>too</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alternate-ly-alternative-ly"><i>Alternate(ly)</i>, <i>alternative(ly)</i></a>
</li>

<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/although-or-though"><i>Although</i> or <i>though</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/altogether-or-all-together"><i>Altogether</i> or <i>all together</i>?</a>
</li>

<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/anyone-anybody-or-anything"><i>Anyone</i>, <i>anybody</i> or <i>anything</i>?</a>

<li class="section">

<li>

<li class="section">
<a>Prepositions and particles</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/above"><i>Above</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/after-afterwards"><i>After</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/against"><i>Against</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/among-and-amongst"><i>Among</i> and <i>amongst</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/at"><i>At</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/at-in-and-to-movement"><i>At</i>, <i>in</i> and <i>to</i> (movement)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/at-on-and-in-place"><i>At</i>, <i>on</i> and <i>in</i> (place)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/at-on-and-in-time"><i>At</i>, <i>on</i> and <i>in</i> (time)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/below"><i>Below</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/beneath"><i>Beneath</i>: meaning and use</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/beyond"><i>Beyond</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/by"><i>By</i> + <i>myself</i> etc.</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/during"><i>During</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/for"><i>For</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/for-ing"><i>For</i> + <i>-ing</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/from"><i>From</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/in-front-of"><i>In front of</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/in-spite-of-and-despite"><i>In spite of</i> and <i>despite</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/in-into"><i>In, into</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/near-and-near-to"><i>Near</i> and <i>near to</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/of"><i>Of</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/on-onto"><i>On</i>, <i>onto</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/over"><i>Over</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/prepositional-phrases">Prepositional phrases</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/prepositions">Prepositions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/to"><i>To</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/under"><i>Under</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/until"><i>Until</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/with"><i>With</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/within"><i>Within</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/without"><i>Without</i></a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Words, sentences and clauses</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-words-clauses-and-sentences">about words, clauses and sentences</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-and-as-expressions"><i>as</i> and <i>as</i> expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/comparing-and-contrasting">comparing and contrasting</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/conditionals-and-wishes">conditionals and wishes</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/linking-words-and-expressions">linking words and expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/questions-and-negative-sentences">questions and negative sentences</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/relative-clauses">relative clauses</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/reported-speech">reported speech</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/so-and-such"><i>so</i> and <i>such</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/word-formation">word formation</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/word-order-and-focus">word order and focus</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Using English</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/discourse-markers">discourse markers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/emphasising-and-downtoning">emphasising and downtoning</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/functions">functions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/numbers">numbers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/people-and-places">people and places</a>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>speaking</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/adverbs-as-short-responses-definitely-certainly">Adverbs as short responses (<i>definitely</i>, <i>certainly</i>)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/all-right-and-alright"><i>All right</i> and <i>alright</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/chunks">Chunks as frames</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/headers-and-tails">Headers and tails</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/here-and-there"><i>Here</i> and <i>there</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/interjections-ouch-hooray">Interjections (<i>ouch, hooray</i>)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/intonation">Intonation</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/just"><i>Just</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/kind-of-and-sort-of"><i>Kind of</i> and <i>sort of</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/oh"><i>Oh</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/pronunciation">Pronunciation</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/question-follow-up-questions">Question: follow-up questions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/questions-echo-and-checking-questions">Questions: echo and checking questions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/questions-short-forms">Questions: short forms</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/so"><i>So:</i> other uses in speaking</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/substitution#speaking-the-date">Substitution</a>
</li>
<li class="section current">
<a>Tags</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/tags#universal-tags-right-yeah">Universal tags: <i>right, yeah</i></a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking/yes"><i>Yes</i></a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/types-of-english-formal-informal-etc">types of English (formal, informal, etc.)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/useful-phrases">useful phrases</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/writing">writing</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Verbs</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-verbs">about verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be-and-be-expressions"><i>be</i> and <i>be</i> expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/common-verbs">common verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/future">future</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/infinitives-and-imperatives">infinitives and imperatives</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality">modals and modality</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/passive">passive</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/past">past</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/present">present</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/verb-patterns">verb patterns</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div class="mod mod--dark mod--style2 oflow-hide">
<div class="pad">
<p class="h2 semi-flush alt">Word of the Day</p>
<p class="h4 feature-w-big wotd-hw">taro</p><p>a tropical plant that has a root that is cooked and eaten</p>
</div>
<div class="txt-block txt-block--alt with-icons js-eqh-sticky">
<div class="with-icons__content">
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/taro" class="a--rev a--b">
<span>About this</span> <i class="fcdo fcdo-angle-right" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</a>
</div>
<div class="with-icons__icons">

</a>

</p>

</p>

</a>

<p class="h4 feature-w semi-flush nw-hw">

</p>
<p>
<small class="smaller"><time>September 24, 2018</time></small>
</p>
</div>
